ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Understanding Mechanisms and Kinetics of Environmentally Assisted Cracking
Mechanismen und Kinetik der von der Umwelt beeinflussten Rissbildung

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: This paper reviews the evidence for an adsorption-induced dislocation-emission (AIDE)/void-coalescence mechanism of liquid-metal embrittlement (LME), hydrogen embrittlement (HE), stress-corrosion cracking (SCC), and corrosion fatigue (CF) in some specific material-environment systems, where cleavage-like or intergranular cracking (or both) occurs in normally ductile materials. Embrittling species (which weaken substrate interatomic bonds at crack tips) include some metal atoms, hydrogen (on the crack-tip surface and at very-near-surface interstitial sites), and complex ions produced by de-alloying. Decohesion due to bond-weakening across grain boundaries associated with adsorbed or segregated hydrogen, in conjunction with segregated impurities, may also occur in some systems. The often-cited hydrogen-enhanced localised-plasticity (HELP) mechanism, based on solute hydrogen facilitating dislocation activity in the plastic zone ahead of cracks, appears to play little (if any) role in cleavage-like and intergranular cracking, and evidence supporting this view is summarised.

Abstract.Heading: Zusammenfassung
Abstract.Para: In diesem Beitrag werden die Hinweise auf eine Adsorptionsinduzierte Versetzungsemission (AIDE)/Fehlstellen-Koaleszenz-Mechanismus bei der Flüssigmetall-Versprödung (LME), der Wasserstoffversprödung (HE), der Spannungsrisskorrosion (SCC) und der Korrosionsermüdung (CF) in einigen spezifischen Material-Umwelt-Systemen untersucht, in denen Quasi-Spaltbruch oder interkristalline Rissbildung bei normalerweise duktilen Werkstoffen auftreten. Zu den versprödenden Spezies, welche die interatomaren Bindungen an Rissspitzen schwächen, gehören einige Metallatome, Wasserstoff (auf der Rissspitzenoberfläche und an sehr oberflächennahen Zwischengitterplätzen) und durch Legierungsauflösung produzierte Komplexionen. Dekohäsion aufgrund von Bindungsschwächung über Korngrenzen verbunden mit adsorbiertem oder getrenntem Wasserstoff, in Verbindung mit geseigerten Verunreinigungen, kann auch in einigen Systemen auftreten. Der oft zitierte Wasserstoff-unterstützte lokalisierte Plastizitäts-Mechanismus (HELP), der darauf basiert, dass gelöster Wasserstoff in der plastischen Zone vor der Rissspitze die Versetzungsbewegung erleichtert, scheint wenig (wenn überhaupt eine) Rolle bei Quasi-Spaltbruch oder interkristalliner Rissbildung zu spielen. Argumente für diese Sicht werden zusammengefasst.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Environmentally assisted cracking of materials, like corrosion, occurs in a wide variety of environments (including earth, water, fire, and air, as highlighted in the conference title). For stress-corrosion cracking (SCC) in aqueous and moist environments, there is often only superficial corrosion, while there is obviously no corrosion when pre-existing internal hydrogen or external hydrogen-gas environments result in hydrogen embrittlement (HE). Similarly, liquid-metal embrittlement (LME) does not involve corrosion in most cases. Failures due to SCC, HE, and LME can be catastrophic and, hence, a huge number of studies have been undertaken over the last 100 years or so in an attempt to understand the mechanisms and kinetics involved – with the aim of preventing failures and developing more-resistant materials. Somewhat surprisingly, given the vast array of experimental and theoretical tools that are now available for studying these phenomena, there are still many unresolved issues and controversies.

One of the reasons for a lack of consensus is that there are so many possible material-environment interactions that can occur at crack tips, especially for aqueous media, e.g. film rupture/re-passivation, localised dissolution, hydrogen generation, adsorption, and diffusion, vacancy generation and diffusion, and hydrogen-vacancy-dislocation interactions. Moreover, corrosion after fracture in aqueous environments can often obscure fine details on fracture surfaces so that valuable information on the processes involved in crack growth is not available. Other reasons for a lack of consensus include: (i) there are no techniques for resolving atomic-scale crack-tip processes in bulk material, (ii) atomistic modelling techniques are not yet sufficiently developed, (iii) commercial materials with complex microstructures are often considered (owing to funding constraints) without seeking guidance from simpler systems, and (iv) some researchers either overlook or ignore evidence that does not agree with their views (and get away with it owing to inadequate refereeing of papers).

In the present review, which draws heavily on previous recent reviews by the present author [1–5], critical observations that shed light on the processes involved are highlighted (in simple systems in the first instance and then in more complex systems). LME is considered first since it is generally the least complex category of environmentally assisted cracking. Interestingly, LME was the first category of environmentally assisted cracking to be recognised—with Pliny (AD 78) [6] mentioning not only the four “classical” elements of fire, air, earth, and water, but also the effects of “quicksilver” (mercury). Thus, Pliny states that “….so penetrant is this liquor, that there is no vessel in the world but it will eat and break through it….”. Pliny’s statement is somewhat an overstatement, but it is now known that mercury can embrittle many metals, including iron, copper, zinc, aluminium, nickel, silver, titanium, and zirconium.

Section1.Heading: Liquid Metal Embrittlement
Section1.Para: It is widely accepted that only adsorption of metal atoms occurs at crack tips in many systems [1–5] since:

ItemContent.Para: sub-critical crack growth can occur at 10’s to 100’s mm/s immediately after substrate metals are wetted by embrittling liquid metals,
embrittlement couples often have low mutual solubilities and do not form compounds,

the characteristics of LME (but not the kinetics) are similar to those produced by solid-metal induced embrittlement and metal-vapour induced embrittlement, where dissolution (even if stress-assisted) cannot occur, and
surface-science studies show that adsorption of metal atoms can have substantial effects on substrate surface-bonding (such that effects on crack growth would not be surprising).

Section1.Para: It was initially thought that adsorption weakened substrate interatomic bonds at crack tips such that ‘decohesion’ (tensile separation of atoms) occurred, resulting in atomically brittle cleavage or intergranular fracture [7]. However, subsequent detailed metallographic and fractographic observations showed that:

ItemContent.Para: extensive localised slip usually occurred around crack tips, especially on planes intersecting crack tips,
dislocation cell structures, indicative of high localised strains, were observed just beneath fracture surfaces,

crack fronts for cleavage-like cracking were parallel to <110> directions for FCC and BCC materials such that slip planes intersected crack fronts even when crystal orientations/local stresses did not favour such directions, and
fracture surfaces were dimpled on a microscopic or nanoscopic scale (sometimes not resolved by SEM) indicating that crack growth occurred by a localised-slip/void-coalescence process.

Section1.Para: The above characteristics have been observed in many single crystal and polycrystalline materials, such as LME of Ni by Hg and Na, Fe-Si by Li, steels by Hg, and Al by Bi alloys (Fig. 1) [1–5]. Other examples are illustrated in subsequent sections where the characteristics of HE and SCC are compared with those for LME. Another consideration favouring a localised slip rather than a decohesion process is that transport of embrittling atoms to rapidly advancing crack tips has to occur by capillary flow (other processes such as surface-diffusion being too slow), and this can only occur if crack tips have a significant radius (probably at least several nanometers) – as would occur if crack growth occurred by localised plasticity but not by decohesion.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: (a), (b) Optical micrographs for pure Al single crystals tested in a liquid Bi-Pb-Sn-In-Cd eutectic at 60 °C showing (a) slip localised on {111} planes intersecting {100} crack on the side surface of a specimen, (b) {100} cleavage-like fracture surface showing V-shaped crack front (delineated by a transition from LME to fatigue in air) along two <110> directions, and (c) TEM of replica of fracture surface showing small, shallow dimples and slip lines (arrowed) produced by slip behind crack tips [5]

Section1.Para: The above observations can be explained on the basis that adsorption of metal atoms weakens interatomic bonds at crack tips and thereby facilitates the nucleation of dislocations [1–5]. Dislocation nucleation at crack tips involves the simultaneous formation of a dislocation core and a surface step by shear movement of atoms within a few atomic distances of crack tips, and such shear displacements are easier when substrate interatomic bonds are weak (providing the bonds between substrate and adsorbate are not too strong). To understand why facilitating dislocation emission from crack tips results in embrittlement, it is first necessary to appreciate that dislocation emission from crack tips in inert (or air) environments is difficult owing to strong interatomic substrate bonds or strong adsorbate-substrate bonds.

In non-embrittling environments, ductile crack growth appears to occur predominantly by egress of dislocations nucleated from sources in the plastic zone ahead of cracks. Only a small proportion of such dislocations would exactly intersect crack tips to produce crack advance – most would produce only blunting by egress just behind crack tips or would contribute to the general strain ahead of crack tips. Large strains are generated ahead of cracks resulting in the nucleation, growth, and coalescence of voids, with considerable blunting occurring at void and crack tips. Thus, large, deep dimples are observed on fracture surfaces – with small, stretched dimples often observed within the larger dimples as a result of the coalescence of large voids, nucleated at large particles, involving nucleation and growth of voids at smaller particles between them (Fig. 2). Voids can also be nucleated at slip-band intersections and other sites.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Schematic diagram illustrating ductile crack growth involving coalescence of cracks with voids by egress of dislocations nucleated from near-crack tip sources

Section1.Para: When adsorption of metal atoms at crack tips promotes dislocation emission, a greater proportion of the dislocation activity results in crack growth because dislocation emission from crack tips on suitably inclined slip planes always produces crack advance (as well as opening). Thus, coalescence of cracks with voids in the plastic zone ahead of cracks occurs at lower strains than in inert environments, and small, shallow dimples are observed on fracture surfaces (Fig. 3). The dimples resulting from the adsorption-induced dislocation-emission (AIDE) void-coalescence process also appear to be smaller than those produced by ductile fracture since, for the latter, small dimples within large dimples are often stretched and difficult to resolve.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Schematic diagram illustrating the adsorption-induced dislocation-emission (AIDE) mechanism involving crack growth by alternate-slip from crack tips, which facilitates the coalescence of cracks with voids formed in the plastic zone ahead of cracks, and results in cleavage-like cracking on low-index planes often at an angle to the applied stress

Section1.Para: Crack paths produced as a result of AIDE mechanism can be intergranular or transgranular (cleavage-like) depending on where dislocation emission and void nucleation occur most easily. For transgranular cracking, alternate slip on planes on either side of the crack tends to occur in order to minimise the back-stress from previously emitted dislocations. Macroscopic fracture planes therefore bisect the angle between the slip planes, and crack fronts lie along the intersection of crack planes and slip planes, i.e. along {100} planes in <110> directions for FCC and BCC materials. However, deviations from these low-index planes and directions occur when unequal amounts of slip occur on either side of the crack when there are large differences in shear stresses on the respective planes.

Section2.Heading: Similarities between HE and Adsorption-Induced LME
Section2.Para: For materials and/or conditions where hydrides do not form, there have been long-standing controversies regarding whether HE is due to adsorbed hydrogen at crack tips or solute hydrogen localised ahead of crack tips. This controversy applies to both internal HE (where pre-existing solute hydrogen can diffuse to and adsorb at internal cracks) and to hydrogen-environment embrittlement (in gaseous H2 or H2S) where hydrogen can adsorb and then diffuse ahead of cracks in most cases. Similarities between HE and adsorption-induced LME are one of many considerations that suggest that the AIDE mechanism is predominantly responsible for cleavage-like and intergranular HE, with solute hydrogen playing little, if any, role [1–4].

For HE, weakening of interatomic bonds at crack tips could be due to hydrogen adsorbed at surface sites and hydrogen in interstitial sites in the first few atomic layers beneath the crack-tip surface. For convenience, hydrogen at both these sites is referred to as adsorbed hydrogen [1–4]. In addition, hydrogen could diffuse to (or be transported by dislocations) to voids ahead of cracks, where it could precipitate as hydrogen gas in voids and adsorb at void tips, especially in BCC materials with high hydrogen diffusivities. The AIDE process for HE could therefore occur at both crack and void tips.

Some proponents of solute-hydrogen based mechanisms have recently dismissed the similarities between HE and LME as being indicative of a common mechanism on the basis that similar fracture-surface appearances are not necessarily produced by the same underlying process [8]. This may well be sometimes the case, e.g. when intergranular fracture surfaces are ‘featureless’ except for occasional tear ridges and slip lines, where decohesion in some cases, or very localised slip processes in other cases, could be involved. However, the case for a common mechanism of HE and LME is especially convincing when the fracture paths, the extent of plasticity, and the richly detailed, fine-scale fracture-surface appearance are all the same (as in the examples shown in the following), particularly when considered in conjunction with other evidence that adsorbed hydrogen rather than solute hydrogen is responsible for cleavage-like and intergranular fractures, as discussed in subsequent sections.

Section3.Heading: HE and LME in Ni
Section3.Para: The metallographic and fractographic similarities between HE (in H2) and LME (in Hg) are especially noteworthy for Ni single crystals [2–4] in that:

ItemContent.Para: The macroscopic fracture planes and directions are the same, viz. near {100} planes in <110> directions, as is the detailed fracture-surface appearance. Note also that the appearance of fracture surfaces varied along crack fronts, but was the same in Hg and H2 for each position (Figs. 4, 5).
The detailed appearance of fracture surfaces depended on the crystal orientation, but was the same in Hg and H2 for each orientation (Figs 5, 6).

The macroscopic and microscopic characteristics of fracture surfaces produced by cyclic loading, e.g. brittle striations, are the same in Hg and H2 for Ni single crystals, as are the slip distributions around cracks ‒ with slip occurring especially on {111} planes intersecting crack fronts (Figs 7, 8).

Section3.Para: The detailed appearance of intergranular fracture surfaces in Ni polycrystals was also similar for Hg and hydrogen environments (Fig. 9).

Section3.Heading: HE and LME in Fe-Si Single Crystals
Section3.Para: Remarkably similar fracture surfaces and slip distributions around crack tips have also been observed for HE and LME of Fe-Si single crystals [2–4]. For Fe-Si single crystals, fracture surfaces produced by HE (in H2) and LME (in Li) were, as for Ni single crystals, essentially identical and exhibited a cleavage-like appearance with a herringbone pattern of steps parallel to the <110> directions of crack growth on near-{100} planes (Fig. 10). On a microscopic scale, TEM fractography showed that there were shallow dimples on fracture surfaces (Fig. 11).

Section3.Heading: HE and LME in High-Strength Steels
Section3.Para: For a high-strength martensitic steel, the fracture-surface appearance and fracture path produced by HE (in H2) and LME (in Hg) depended on the tempering condition of the steel, but were generally similar for each temper [2–4]. For example, microscopically dimpled transgranular fractures (with respect to prior-austenite grains) were observed for material tempered at 290°C, ‘brittle’ intergranular fractures (exhibiting nano-scale dimples) along prior-austenite grain boundaries were observed for material tempered at 400 to 550°C, and microscopically dimpled intergranular fractures were observed for material tempered at 650°C (Figs 12–14).

Section2.Heading: Experimental Evidence that Adsorbed Hydrogen Can Produce HE
Section2.Para: Both adsorbed and solute hydrogen are present for most testing conditions, but there are circumstances where only adsorbed hydrogen is present and HE occurs. For example, studies of fatigue cracking (along intergranular and transgranular paths) in Ni polycrystals in hydrogen gas [9] have shown that crack-growth rates are increased (by up to 50 × compared with crack-growth rates in nitrogen) at low temperatures (down to − 196°C) where hydrogen-diffusion rates, D, are so slow (D ~ 10− 29 cm2/s at − 196°C [4]) that hydrogen would not diffuse ahead of cracks (Fig. 15).

In another study, tensile tests on notched Ni single crystals in gaseous hydrogen produced cleavage-like fractures at − 130°C (D ~ 10− 17 cm2/s) where hydrogen diffusion ahead of cracks would be unlikely to occur even at the slow strain rates used [4]. At 20°C (D ~ 10− 14 cm2/s), cleavage-like cracking of fatigue pre-cracked Ni single crystals in gaseous hydrogen has been observed at crack velocities ~ 0.2 mm/s at very high crack-opening-displacement rates, such that there would no time for diffusion of hydrogen more than several atomic distances ahead of cracks [2–4].

An embrittlement site very close to crack tips is also supported by the abrupt transitions in fracture-surface appearance produced on changing environmental conditions, e.g. changing from hydrogen to oxygen or argon gas (and vice versa) (Fig. 16), or adding oxygen to hydrogen-gas environments [1–4]. Similarly, detailed analyses of the effects of hydrogen-gas pressure and temperature on crack-growth kinetics in Fe-Si and Ni single crystals [10] indicate that embrittlement occurs within ~ 5 nm of crack tips rather than in the general plastic zone – which is also consistent with an adsorbed hydrogen mechanism.

Section2.Heading: Other Considerations Consistent with Adsorption-induced HE
Section2.Para: Additional support for an adsorption mechanism for HE, as detailed elsewhere [2–4] and references therein, includes:

ItemContent.Para: High hydrogen concentrations on surfaces and within one or two atomic distances of surfaces,

Surface-science observations that adsorbed hydrogen, like metal adsorbates, can produce substantial changes in bonding at surfaces, e.g. changes in surface relaxations/reconstructions, and changes in surface stresses,
Modelling predictions that dislocations would be emitted from crack tips more easily when adsorbed hydrogen is present due to lowering of the unstable stacking-fault energy,

Some quantum-mechanical based modelling indicating that adsorbed hydrogen can facilitate dislocation emission from crack tips (when slip planes intersect crack fronts along their length as is often the case), and
Thermodynamic ‘defactant’ arguments involving hydrogen lowering the formation energy of defects in general (including dislocations), thereby enhancing defect production.

Section2.Heading: Observations that Solute Hydrogen: Dislocation Interactions Are Not Generally Significant for HE
Section2.Para: There is no doubt that hydrogen atmospheres around dislocations, and hydrogen at dislocation cores, can affect their movement. Hydrogen can facilitate dislocation activity in some circumstances, e.g. when hydrogen atmospheres can form and can keep up with mobile dislocations, reducing interaction stresses with obstacles [8], but can inhibit it in other circumstances, e.g. when hydrogen atmospheres are not sufficiently mobile and thereby pin dislocations (resulting in serrated yielding) [2–4]. However, there is no convincing evidence that the degree of local softening (HELP) (or hardening) is sufficiently large that significant effects on fracture would be expected [2–4]. Indeed, numerous observations suggest that solute-hydrogen:dislocation-interactions do not have significant effects on cleavage-like and intergranular fracture [2–4], as summarised below:

ItemContent.Para: For hydrogen-charged notched Ni single crystals at 20°C, fatigue cracking in air resulted in ‘ductile’ fatigue striations with the same spacing and appearance as observed on fractures of hydrogen-free specimens (Fig. 17).

CaptionContent.SimplePara: SEM of fracture surfaces produced by fatigue (at 1 Hz, 20°C, and at the same ∆K) in air for nickel single crystals (a) hydrogen-free, and (b) hydrogen-charged (0.45at.%H), showing similarly spaced ‘ductile’ striations for both conditions

ItemContent.Para: For hydrogen-charged Ni single crystals tested under slowly increasing crack-opening displacements after fatigue pre-cracking, ductile fracture predominated, with large deep dimples on fracture surfaces, except for some cleavage-like areas around some of the large dimples (Fig. 18) – which can be explained on the basis that hydrogen diffuses (or is transported by dislocations) to voids where it precipitates as hydrogen gas and is adsorbed at void surfaces. Transitions from ductile void growth to cleavage-like cracking then occurs when a critical hydrogen pressure/adsorbed hydrogen concentration is attained.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: SEMs of fracture surface produced in a hydrogen-charged nickel single crystal (0.45 at.% H) tested in air at low cracking velocities (10−4 mm/s), showing (a) mostly ductile behaviour with dimples (D) and stretched areas (S), plus isolated cleavage-like islands (C) and (b) detailed appearance of cleavage-like region surrounding a deep dimple

ItemContent.Para: Cleavage-like cracking (with similar characteristics and strains to failure) occurs in notched Ni single crystals over a wide range of temperatures (20°C to − 130°C), and hydrogen would be expected to diffuse ahead of cracks (albeit to varying extents) above about − 50°C – but would probably inhibit dislocation activity below about 0°C and facilitate activity at 20°C. These opposite effects of solute hydrogen would be unlikely to result in similar fracture characteristics, whereas adsorbed hydrogen (expected to occur for the whole temperature range of interest) could produce HE with similar characteristics.

For hydride-forming materials with high concentrations of solute hydrogen, large strains can sometimes be accommodated (without cleavage-like cracking from incipient voids/cracks), and it is only when brittle hydride phases are formed that HE occurs.

For a hydrogen-charged β-Ti alloy with high solute hydrogen concentrations (up to 0.2 H/M at 20°C), ductile (dimpled) transgranular fracture occurs, and then there is an abrupt transition to cleavage-like fracture at a higher (temperature-dependent) hydrogen concentration (Fig. 19) [11]. Such behaviour is difficult (if not impossible) to explain in terms of solute-hydrogen effects on dislocation activity, but could possibly be due to a crack-tip-surface phase transition (resulting in weakening of interatomic bonds) at a critical, temperature-dependent hydrogen concentration [2–4].

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Plot of strain to failure versus hydrogen concentration for β-titanium alloy tensile specimens tested in air at a strain rate of 10−5 s−1, showing sharp, temperature-dependent transitions associated with changes from ductile dimpled fracture to cleavage-like fracture, as shown in the accompanying SEMs. (Adapted from Teter et al. [11])

ItemContent.Para: For cleavage-like fractures, it is difficult to see how just localising and facilitating dislocation activity due to solute hydrogen ahead of cracks (HELP) would result in a change from ductile dimpled fracture in inert environments to cleavage-like fractures on specific crystallographic planes in specific crystallographic directions in hydrogen environments.

For hydrogen-charged polycrystals, the preference for intergranular cracking in many materials is difficult to understand on the basis of solute-hydrogen:dislocation interactions because such interactions would not be expected to occur preferentially in regions adjacent to grain boundaries ahead of cracks vis-à-vis regions ahead of transgranular cracks. However, monolayer segregation of hydrogen would be expected at grain boundaries, such that intergranular crack-tip bonding would be weakened thereby facilitating dislocation emission or decohesion. Bonding at grain boundaries may also be weakened by other segregants, e.g. metalloid impurities in steels, in conjunction with hydrogen. Hydrogen probably also adsorbs at intergranular crack tips from gaseous hydrogen within internal grain-boundary cracks, with hydrogen diffusing or transported by dislocations to such cracks during testing.

Section2.Heading: Summary
Section2.Para: The evidence for an adsorption-based mechanism of HE (when hydrides do not form) is compelling and, in most cases, the metallographic and fractographic observations (when sufficiently high-resolution techniques are used) suggest that cleavage-like and intergranular cracking occur by a localised-plasticity/void-coalescence process. Taken together, the above strongly supports the adsorption-induced dislocation-emission (AIDE)/void-coalescence HE hypothesis for most cleavage-like and intergranular fractures. However, there may well be some instances of intergranular cracking where decohesion along grain boundaries predominates. There is no evidence that solute-hydrogen:dislocation interactions are significant for cleavage-like or intergranular fractures, but they could be important for slip-band cracking, e.g. in Ni superalloys, owing to solute hydrogen promoting slip planarity [2–4].

Section1.Heading: Hydrogen Assisted Stress Corrosion Cracking
Section1.Para: For SCC (and CF) of many materials in aqueous environments, hydrogen is generated at crack tips by dissociation of water molecules or electrochemical reactions, and it is widely accepted that hydrogen somehow facilitates crack growth. Not surprisingly, there are the same controversies regarding the exact mechanism(s), as discussed for HE in the previous section. Additionally, the roles of dissolution, film formation, and other processes need to be considered for cracking in aqueous environments as mentioned in the introduction. Notwithstanding the complexities, there is compelling evidence that the AIDE/void-coalescence mechanism discussed for HE is also applicable to SCC/CF in some cases (but certainly not all) [1], as summarised for some specific materials and environments in the following.

Section2.Heading: SCC and CF in Aluminium Alloys
Section2.Para: SCC in Al alloys is generally intergranular, but transgranular SCC occurs occasionally, while transgranular CF is common. Transgranular cracking is less complicated than intergranular cracking and, hence, is considered first. Critical observations for T-SCC, which has been studied in detail in age-hardened Al-Zn-Mg single crystals [1], include:

ItemContent.Para: Cleavage-like cracking on (or near) {100} planes in < 110 > directions, with slip on {111} planes intersecting cracks, with velocities ranging from 10–7 mm/s under sustained loading in moist air to 10 mm/s under rapid dynamic loading in aqueous environments (Fig. 20).

ItemContent.Para: Nano-scale dimples on fracture surfaces (resolved by high-resolution TEM of replicas) – with larger nano-scale dimples observed for more overaged conditions, consistent with nanovoids being nucleated by age-hardening precipitates (Fig. 21).

Section2.Para: All the above observations are consistent with an AIDE/void-coalescence mechanism since, for example, there would be no time for other reactions such as hydrogen diffusion ahead of cracks at high crack velocities and, as for HE, evidence that solute hydrogen ahead of cracks (which could be present at low crack velocities) is not embrittling. There is also widespread agreement that localised dissolution cannot account for cleavage-like cracking [1].

For intergranular SCC, fracture surfaces are characterised by brittle facets exhibiting grain-boundary precipitates and, in some cases, crack-arrest markings (CAMs) (Fig. 24), although such features may sometimes be obscured by corrosion products. The presence of CAMs (and other evidence that crack growth involves rapid crack jumps and periods of crack-arrest) suggests that hydrogen generated at crack tips may diffuse ahead of cracks and segregate at grain boundaries during crack-arrest periods so that bonding across boundaries is weakened. Crack-growth increments could then occur by decohesion or localised slip when a critical hydrogen concentration over a critical distance is achieved [1].

CaptionContent.SimplePara: SEM of fracture surface of intergranular fracture surface produced by slow crack growth in moist air for a 7079-T651 aluminium alloy under sustained loading, showing crack-arrest markings

Section2.Para: Rates of hydrogen generation probably control SCC velocities, and the potential difference between MgZn2(Cu) grain-boundary precipitates and adjacent areas is important in this regard. For example, overaging decreases SCC velocities by orders of magnitude probably because grain-boundary precipitates become more enriched in Cu, thereby reducing the potential difference between precipitates and adjacent areas such that hydrogen-generation rates are reduced [1].

Section2.Heading: SCC in Magnesium Alloys (and Pure Mg)
Section2.Para: SCC in HCP Mg alloys and pure Mg in aqueous environments often occurs preferentially along transgranular crack paths, but intergranular cracking can also occur [1]. Critical observations (some of which mirror those for Al alloys) that support an adsorbed-hydrogen based mechanism, include:

(a) SEM of fracture surface produced by rapid cracking (v ~ 10 mm/s) first in NaCl + K2CrO4 solution and then in dry air, showing that flutes/dimples are shallower after rapid cracking in the salt solution than after cracking in air – shown more clearly in (b) and (c) by TEM of replicas. Note also secondary {0001} cracks for SCC

ItemContent.Para: Similar cleavage-like and fluted fractures at low and high SCC velocities.
No evidence of hydride formation during SCC in aqueous environments (although hydrides can form in Mg in some circumstances).
Close similarities between SCC and adsorption-induced LME (Fig. 27).

Section2.Heading: SCC in Titanium Alloys
Section2.Para: SCC of Ti alloys in aqueous environments, like Mg alloys, produces low-energy cleavage-like and fluted fractures – with the former occurring not only on basal planes but also on planes 12–15° away from basal planes, with no evidence of hydride phases associated with such fractures [1]. Essentially identical fracture-surface appearances and crystallography are produced by adsorption-induced LME (Fig. 28) which, along with other observations, support an adsorbed-hydrogen based mechanism for some of the reasons discussed for Al alloys and in other sections [1].

CaptionContent.SimplePara: SEMs of cleavage-like and fluted fractures produced at 20°C by (a) slow crack growth in an aqueous environment and (b) rapid cracking in liquid mercury, in a Ti6 %Al4 %V alloy

Section2.Heading: SCC in Ferritic Steels
Section2.Para: For high-strength martensitic steels, I-SCC along prior-austenite grain boundaries is much more common than T-SCC, but cleavage-like cracking does occur to some extent, depending on steel purity and other variables (Fig. 29). For low strength steels, such as those used in pipelines, the crack path depends on the local environment (especially pH), with I-SCC predominating for high pH conditions in concentrated carbonate/bi-carbonate solutions and T-SCC occurring for low or near neutral pH solutions. I-SCC in high-strength steels is usually attributed to an effect of hydrogen (probably HEDE with contributions from AIDE), while I-SCC in low-strength steels is usually attributed to localised dissolution. For cleavage-like cracking, the AIDE mechanism probably predominates, as discussed previously for other systems exhibiting cleavage-like cracking. Such hypotheses are reasonable based on the observations for the model systems, and comparisons of SCC with HEE, IHE and LME [1].

CaptionContent.SimplePara: SEM of fracture surface produced by SCC of a 300 M high-strength martensitic steel aircraft component in an aqueous environment, showing predominantly intergranular facets with small areas of cleavage-like cracking

Section1.Heading: Stress Corrosion Cracking not Involving Hydrogen

Section2.Heading: SCC in Copper and Silver Alloys
Section2.Para: SCC of FCC alloys, such as Cu-Zn, Cu-Au, and Ag-Au alloys is associated with de-alloying at crack-tips, and there is a strong correlation between increasing rates of SCC and increasing rates of de-alloying as the concentration of the less-noble alloying element increases [1, 12]. De-alloying (selective corrosion) results in a nano-porous film that is macroscopically brittle, but fractures by localised shear of nano-scale ligaments. Critical observations include:

ItemContent.Para: SCC (under sustained loading) occurs by rapid crack jumps followed by periods of crack-arrest, with CAMs often produced on fracture surfaces (Fig. 30): Crack-jump distances vary between 1 µm and 100 µm, and crack velocities during crack jumps are about 100 µm/s [1, 13].

SCC results in cleavage-like {110} fracture surfaces or ‘brittle’ intergranular facets (or both) – depending on the testing conditions – and there is generally evidence of localised plasticity, e.g. high-resolution TEM fractography shows that cleavage-like fracture surfaces are ‘rumpled’ and that nano-scale dimples are probably present (Fig. 31).

For single crystal wires/foils (20 to 125 µm diameter/thickness) that are de-alloyed (without applied stresses) for less than 10 % of the specimen cross-section and then immediately dynamically loaded in the SCC environment, cleavage-like cracking at high velocities (1–20 mm/s) occurs across the remaining cross-section (or across most of the cross-section before transitioning to ductile fracture) (Fig. 32). If specimens are not tested immediately, then ductile behaviour is observed [12].

Section2.Para: The above observations are best explained [1] on the basis that de-alloying produces a concentrated ionic solution within the nano-porous film and that, when the film fractures, adsorption of specific ions on the unfilmed substrate results in AIDE or decohesion until the supply of embrittling liquid is exhausted. Crack-arrest then occurs (under sustained loading) or a transition to ductile fracture occurs (under dynamic loading). Ductile fracture occurs if there is a delay time before testing under dynamic loading probably because the concentrated ionic liquid becomes diluted by mixing with less concentrated liquid further from the crack tip such that it is no longer embrittling.

Comparisons of SCC with LME support the above hypothesis for I-SCC since brittle intergranular fractures are observed in both cases. Cleavage-like LME fractures of Cu alloys have not been observed (even in single crystals) in any of the liquid-metal environments used, but cleavage-like cracking has been occasionally observed on {110} planes in Al alloys (although {100} planes are much more common). Alternative explanations for SCC in de-alloying systems, such as ‘film-induced cleavage’ [12], can be discounted on various grounds, as discussed in detail elsewhere [1].

ItemContent.Para: The remarkable similarities between liquid-metal embrittlement and hydrogen embrittlement/stress-corrosion cracking in materials such as Ni, Fe, Al, Ti, and Mg suggest that a common mechanism involving adsorption-induced weakening of interatomic bonds at crack tips is responsible.

Environmentally assisted cracking in hydrogen and aqueous environments at high crack velocities (relative to hydrogen-diffusion rates) under dynamic loading in some FCC and HCP metals supports an adsorption-based mechanism ‒ not only for high crack-growth rates but also at low crack growth rates under sustained loads, since the characteristics of cracking are similar for both high and low rates.
An adsorption-based mechanism is consistent with surface-science, atomistic modeling, and thermodynamic considerations.

Embrittling adsorbed species include some metal atoms, hydrogen, and complex ions produced by de-alloying, but adsorbates such as oxygen which form strong bonds with the substrate are not embrittling.

Metallographic and fractographic observations indicate that environmentally assisted cleavage-like and intergranular cracking generally involves localised plasticity and void formation (often on a nanoscale) ahead of cracks, and support an adsorption-induced dislocation-emission mechanism.

Decohesion may occur for intergranular cracking in some very high strength materials owing to adsorbed hydrogen or hydrogen segregated at grain boundaries. For materials where there are anodic phases at grain boundaries, dissolution-based mechanisms are probably involved.

Solute-hydrogen/dislocation interactions ahead of cracks do not play a significant role for cleavage-like and intergranular cracking, and proponents of the HELP mechanism not only ignore evidence that is inconsistent with such a mechanism, but also do not properly consider evidence for the AIDE model.
